The food was standard dive-breakfast food. Eggs, bacon and toast. Greasy yet delicious.
author: Julie J.

description:
Om nom nom. This is my and my roommates go to spot for hungover breakfast. A great, fast, tasty diner. I really like their omelets and French toast.

I think the place is family run because there's always the same three people there who look related. So good.
author: Andrew R.

description: It was our good fortune to have such a fantastic breakfast place so near our hotel.  Literally every day that we vacationed in San Francisco we went here for breakfast.  The food is prepared right in front of you. There isn't anything kept under a heat lamp.  If you order sausage the owner puts sausage on the grill if you order steak he grills a steak.  Golden Coffee shop is so light and airy with big windows to people watch out of.  If I ever have the oppurtinity to return to San Franciso this will be a must stop each and every visit.
author: Lucretiz C.

description:
How does this place have 4 stars?? The place is gross, food is gross and the service can be way better. 
I order 2 eggs, hash browns and sausage for $5.95. When I get it I needed to pat down the puddles of oil on the plate and eggs... I order this all the time everywhere and I never seen my dish sooooo greasy! 
Also, I got very little hash browns! There was more sausage than there was hash browns! For $5.95 I wasn't expecting much but for what I got this was overpriced. I get the bill and it comes out to $8.10... And I didn't order anything extra.. Already frustrated I just leave a $10 and leave. I came in for a fair $5.95 dish and not only did I not get what I paid for but I was overcharged and left hungry. Yes this dump is cheap, but you do not even get what you pay for!!!
author: Tim V.

description: This is by all means a hole in the wall and not a very good one.  The interior is cold and unwelcoming.  The waffle I ordered was super hard and dry.  They charged me $1.75 for a scoop of blueberries and the orange juice is straight out of a generic box.  Yeah it's cheap but I rather pay more and get food made with quality ingredients.  Cash only!
author: Monica G.

description:
(Hearts, hearts, hearts)

Love, love, laaaahv' this little diner. Was here for the first time ever on my last trip to ze' bay and I absolutely head over heels. It's very tiny in here. I think it sits about 15-20 people. There is a wait outside for seating and there are no rest areas. 

I remember our wait was about 10-15 minutes but it was OK because we were enjoying the SF streets.

As soon as we were due, we went in and sat. Ordered and within 10 minutes, our breakfast was out. Every bite was heavenly!

Despite the fact that I was playing elbow wars w/ the people next to me, I still loved it.

Food is cheap, good, and service is good. I can't wait to go back
author: Diana V.

description:
I stopped by here for the first time to grab a bite to eat as I was so craving a Cheeseburger.  I've tried out Han's across the street but wanted to give this spot a try.

Beyond the two tables by the window, it's all counter seating.  The layout of the resto is cool because if you're sitting facing Leavenworth, you definitely get a nice view of everything; people sitting across from you, people walking up/down Sutter and Leavenworth, well, just good ol' people watching in general!

Looking through the menu, I always get captivated by breakfast as it's my favorite meal of the day.  My intention was to get a Cheeseburger and what did I end up ordering?  A "Joe's Special" omelet!  My omelet came out quick and were accompanied with hash browns, cooked just the way I like it.  Portions were adequate.  Quality and taste of my omelet was really good.  They also managed to keep my coffee cup full; pretty good coffee for a greasy spoon, total thumbs up from me!

Service was super friendly and they're not yelling at each other as they do at Han's across the street.  It looks like it's a family run business, I think, with the dad as the cook, mom doing the bussing, and daughter up front.

I'd totally hit up Golden Coffee Shop again!  Between this spot and Han's across the street, I like GCS better.
author: Nick D.

description: Exactly what a diner should be. Their set up is really cute, too--it's amazing what they can cook in that little space! Yummy, simple and cheap--finding this trifecta is increasingly rare in SF!
author: Elle N M.

description:
Love this place...but for Kong P....Upper Middle Class (what you are) is not the 1%. Yes the food is not sourced from a farm in Napa or something, but for what it is, it's great!

P.S. Don't order the pork chop next time
author: Mark G.

description:
I don't see what all the fuss is about.  The service is great because the owner is a cute little Asian lady but to be honest... she can't make food for shit.  

I ordered the pork chops and eggs.  The pork was overcooked so it was very tough (I couldn't even cut it with a knife).  The eggs were undercooked and very watery.  

The orange juice was ok... probably because it came from a store-bought bottle of minute maid.  

The venue looks run down and worse than your average hole in the wall diner. 

The only great part about this place is the price.  Food is very cheap but as a part of the 1%, that is something I don't care too much about.  

If you think that was douchey for me to say, then you're probably just sad because you're part of the 99%.  Suck it.
author: Kong P.

description:
Okay, very affordable breakfast--major plus.  This place is ZERO frills, extremely basic breakfast menu.  
That being said, I simply can't give it a very high rating because everything they served I could make at home (and largely with better ingredients).  I also questioned how sanitary everything was...probably not for you if you're looking for a nice, leisurely breakfast.
author: Liz H.

description: Nice little restaurant, cafe bar style spot. Food was good, really home made. Really fast you can be in and out in no time. Very locally owned and operated place where if you go often them might just know your name.
author: Elfego S.

description: awesome little hole in the wall. Delicious food and nice people
author: Graydon C.

description:
Golden Coffee Shop serves up breakfast at fairly unbelievable prices, for the city anyhow. That's really the only unbelievable thing though. The food itself is standard fare, for breakfast anyway. Things such as the thin waffles most diners make, flat pancakes, breakfast staples like eggs and toast and kind of watery coffee are the staples here. Is there anything wrong with that? Not at all my friends. Sometimes simple is what this girl wants and when the hankering hits I don't need farm fresh strawberries and cream from a cow that was milked out back atop my waffles to make it good. I need cheap butter and sugary syrup. So, if you have those moods like I do and a deficit in your pocket you should hit up Golden Coffee Shop and enjoy your 5 buck breakfast. 

Be ware - it's a small place and a wait can occur sometimes. I have to say I personally wouldn't wait, but I do know others that do.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I would say this breakfast joint was actually not that bad. They served us quickly and made us delicious american breakfast. You can tell its a family owned joint in the TL. I had the egg scramble and it was not bad. I definitely had to add some pepper and hot sauce. 

Cash only. I'd go back again but wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: Carlos C.

description:
Again and again, this place is worth a thousand positive words. 

Many will see this place as a not so fancy place, so leave. Go across the street for a $7 orange juice w/no refill. 

Not everyone is able to "GET" this place or come close to understand what it is or how important it is as a part of a small community within a large community. This is a mom and pops place. Nothing has changed since day one to preserve the personable homey vibe and ambiance. I've only came close to one other place like it in the outskirts of downtown Napa. This is the place where you can come in day after day, get the same affordable food, sit up at the counter, and just enjoy hearty food cooked from scratch. 

The chef behind it all is also the owner. He used to be a head chef at a 4 star restaurant within a hotel and had refocused by being at his own diner full time. He cooks and buys all his ingredients himself! If you had a blindfold on, you would swear you're at a fancy place while savoring the home cooked meals. 

Eat with your taste buds, not with your eyes.
author: Thomas C.

description: Lots of memories from my breakfasts here with friends in the city before I moved to San Francisco. There's a reason we kept going back, and I still make my way over from time to time.
author: David S.

description:
Cozy little Mom and Pops cafe. Food is good worth the wait. Don't expect anything fancy.  If you are in town you should totally try it. 
Park in the street. Be prepared to wait at least 20 minutes for food. Not much for sitting. 
2 thumbs up
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I love yelp. You helped Me find amazing breakfast places near my hotel which I otherwise wouldnt walk into. 

This place is a family run diner. Cheap dishes averaging $5 to $6 each be it French toast with eggs, huge scrambled eggs or corned beef hash (really good)

Breakfast for $15 including taxes. Yum!
author: Laura C T.

description:
Would you believe the Golden Coffee Shop in the Tendernob has a lot in common with Chez Maman in Potrero Hill? Uh-huh. Seriously. Think about it. They both have wide-open kitchens, long counters, just two tables and four people maneuvering in highly cramped quarters. From that point, the comparison falters as the Golden Coffee Shop is a dive, pure and simple. I just wish they served hearty comfort food to balance out the spartan surroundings. 

That's not to say the owners don't take their business seriously. They're a grim-faced crew very focused on the dine-and-dash breakfasts they serve there. The place was fairly packed when I got there around 10:30AM on Saturday. I noticed there was a lone stool right at the edge of the grill and sink where - for better or worse - I had an unblemished view of the entire operation. In fact, they kept placing the dirty dishes and glasses right in front of me since the sink was beneath me to the left. If they gave me a pair of extra-large Playtex gloves, I would have definitely pitched in rather than stare at them during my meal. 

Obviously, this place has its devotees, and you certainly can't beat the price - $6 for their Joe's Special, which comes with hash browns and toast (see my photo). That's about half the price of the same dish at the SoMa Inn Cafe. But I have to tell you that the eggs had that slightly aged flavor that I found none too pleasing. The people watching, however, is great if nobody catches you staring at them. Regardless, I don't think I'll be back any time soon. If I want serious grease in my food, I've got artery clogging options closer to my 'hood. 

FOOD - 2 stars...hmm, that tainted egg taste doesn't quite leave your tongue, does it? 
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...I think I remember a roadside diner scene in "The Grapes of Wrath" that kinda looked like this place 
SERVICE - 2. stars...very serious but could you move those dirty dishes please? 
TOTAL - 2 stars...I shall grease my spoon elsewhere
author: Ed U.

description:
ATTENTION: ultimate hangover cure served here
Great location, great prices, and yummy food.
I don't think there is anywhere else in the city I can go to get three entrées and three bottomless coffees for only 20 bucks. The people are friendly and the service is awesome.
author: Jasmine N.

description:
I wanted to try Farmtable about a block away from Golden Coffee Shop but there were no seating on the communal table, which only seated six to eight people.

Luckily, I planned Golden Coffee as my alternate. The decor was worse than any diner I've been to... almost ran down.  But what made it quaint was the husband and wife that worked the shop. Hearing them speak in Cantonese reminded me of my folks. That alone made the meal enjoyable.

The prices were reasonable.., two eggs and pancakes for $4.75. I added corn beef and hash for another $2.75. With coffee, the bill came right under $10.  You seriously can't beat this price in the city.

It is definitely worth it if you needed to eat and run.
author: Tuan C.

description:
This place is a complete dump.  And by "complete dump", I mean "absolutely delicious".  I could eat breakfast here every day.   It is the quintessential greasy spoon.

The guy who cooks the breakfast right in front of you is a master at eggs and hashbrowns.  He cooks the eggs perfectly, flips them without use of a spatula, shreds his potatoes by hand and cooks them to a perfect crispiness on the flat top.  He does this all while yielding a mysterious "butter mop", which he uses on just about everything and is, most likely, responsible for much of the tastiness.   The corned beef hash with eggs is so good that I had to have it twice in three days.

Surprise dish that you'll love:  Pork Chops and Eggs.

I think you'd be turned off if the kitchen was hidden in the back, but here you can see that the guy is using fresh ingredients and is turning out a non-stop ton of food.   Food comes out here one plate at a time because he cooks everything to perfection and doesn't let it sit around.   Perfect breakfast.
author: Chris U.

description:
I have to wonder, how does Golden Coffee Shop make any profit with the prices they charge? I mean, the overhead along can't be cheap with SF being the second least affordable city in the US. Not that I actually fret over this much since it means more savings for me!

This no-frills and very small (~15 stools around the counter and 2 tables of four) family-run café epitomizes the neighbourhood greasy spoon diner. It's not a place you would go for the atmosphere, but you are guaranteed to get solid food at dirt cheap prices. They serve all the breakfast staples (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rBwyayyqFMD8chqenrRxag?select=y_LO-WrGT_L1PaIr6G4UPA) plus "American" lunch fare (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rBwyayyqFMD8chqenrRxag?select=t0tH9JqHpgMEVYa7Xoldpw), and even Chinese food (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rBwyayyqFMD8chqenrRxag?select=Cuc8RudhXTG-sGZVyxNtuQ).

My friend and I enjoyed a carb feast (think waffles, French toast, pancakes, hash browns, and toast) that would make any Atkins enthusiast shake in their boots. We got:

*WAFFLE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rBwyayyqFMD8chqenrRxag?select=asBDICt90uErvMQyY4Whfw): Although I'm partial to the thicker and larger-pocketed Belgian waffle, I was very happy with the thinner Eggo-like waffle I had here. The batter tasted great and, more importantly, it was crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. I loved it!

*FRENCH TOAST (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rBwyayyqFMD8chqenrRxag?select=XBpaqyx_Ezca7gqov78iJw): Not the best I've had but still very good. I liked how eggy the outsides were but I prefer my French toast moister.

*PANCAKE SANDWICH (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rBwyayyqFMD8chqenrRxag?select=LHTcGYwkIxJp-6AmFTq-Pw): The moist buttermilk pancakes were cooked just right with a nicely browned crust. (There's nothing worse than gummy, undercooked pancakes!) While they were a little on the dense side they still maintained a certain fluffiness. My over easy egg was perfectly cooked and the yolk oozed out beautifully. I wasn't a huge fan of the sausages though since they were all shriveled.

*SPANISH OMELET (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rBwyayyqFMD8chqenrRxag?select=51PSM1gGecJqX365M4OhFQ): Not your typical omelet as the fillings were placed on top of the folded eggs. The tomato sauce was a little too sweet but I still liked it. On the plus side the egg itself was light and fluffy. The best part of the dish were the hash browns--super crispy on the outside, soft and moist on the inside. The shredded potatoes had the perfect texture and weren't mushy at all. I could've eaten a whole plate of them! (This dish also came with toast, which I'm not gonna comment much on since toast is toast. Unless it's bad toast--which these were not.)

Overall, my stomach was very happy. My wallet was even happier since all this food only set us back $23 including tip.
author: Steph L.

description: I love this place! Looks like a small family owned place, a bit divey but the food is a good simple meal, super affordable and quick. You watch "dad" cook while you sit in the pink room at the u shaped bar waiting for your meal.  It's CASH ONLY so make sure you have that sorted out.  It's  a nice simple meal served by good people. I enjoyed my two eggs, toast, hashed browns (crispy and perfect)  and my coffee.   It also seems like a  spot where most of the bar is filled with regulars...which makes it fun. two thumbs up.
author: Maren H.

description: Charming diner in the Tendernob with a U shaped counter to sit at. No frills service but always fast and efficient, run by a nice Chinese family (the grandfather who works the grill- we call him "the dragon" - he makes perfectly crispy bacon and perfect fried eggs!). LOVE this place!  Also it's not on the menu but I always sub out rice for hash browns, bc what is better than sunny side up eggs over rice?!  This is one of my favorite breakfast spots in SF, classic diner food in a cool spot!
author: CC C.

description:
cute mom and pop joint.

corned beef hash w/ overeasy eggs
pork chops w/ overeasy eggs
side order french toast
author: Rebecca C.

description: I loved this itty bitty tiny place! Mom/pop place. Just a good old fashioned breakfast, cooked perfectly ( real shredded hash browns) at prices that are easy on ya!
author: Evie B.

description: This is without a doubt the best greasy spoon in the city, and more than that, a rare gem. You sit at a peripheral counter facing strangers for breakfast in a little tiny restaurant, while the staff serves from the center. The prices are unbelievably low and fair for the quality of the food. We're talking $6-$7 for a quite a large meal. My favorite diner-type breakfast spot in the city.
author: Christian S.

description:
Golden Coffee is not the place to take your lady to impress her. It IS, however, the place to take your lady when you've both spent the previous evening drinking cheap whiskey in the Castro and you're so hungover that you're wearing shades and smoking bowls just so that you're able to realize that you are left without the strength to cook yourself something to cure your ailment.

The coffee is hot. The food is simple, no frills. You need eggs and hash browns, maybe a waffle, maybe some fried rice? No problem, this is the spot. Are you so hungover that you're actually thinking about eating a hamburger patty wrapped in a pancake? That can be done, too.

A few helpful tips:
- Cash only
- There is a U shaped seating bar around the kitchen. There are two tables that seat 4 each. It's a tiny spot. Consider whether you are in shape enough to be holding yourself up on a bar stool.
- I avoid this spot on the weekends. It's tiny. It gets busy. I get grumpy when I'm hungry.

Golden Coffee, you're a life saver.
author: Reishi A.

description:
Price: Only need to spend under $8 for good food and coffee. 

Place: Sometime need to sit next to the strangers, so I always have the headphone in my ear with some good music. 

Products: I usually order the French toast for lunch. The fresh egg flavor and the fairish icing sugar are the best combination.
author: 春枝

description:
This place is right across the street from Han's. Golden Coffee Shop is, admittedly, a bit grimy even for my tastes, and it's packed full of regulars. Some of whom are kind of odd. But if you get past that, the food's pretty good! I completely agree that the pancakes are a little on the dense side but are quite tasty and really nicely cooked with crisp edges. I was actually pretty impressed with how orange the egg yolk was, and it was pretty flavorful. The bacon is not as crisp as I'd like, but not bad, and I personally liked the sausages, although they were a bit small. And everything's quite cheap (seemed easy to get a full breakfast for around five bucks). Coffee's what you'd expect (weak but plenty of it!). The service was friendly, prompt, and not intrusive.

Overall, I wouldn't wait around for a seat here. I think the counter's especially good for people dining alone, but having tried this place out, I imagine I'd probably stick to Han's in the future.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Based on previous reviews, had breakfast : sausage, eggs, toast & bacon, eggs, toast. Eggs cooked just right, meats cooked on order. With drinks & hash browns less than $15 for 2!!  Small place, only 3 people behind the counter. Looks like a dive, but looks are deceiving. Looked like several regulars at the counter.  Lunch menu just as inexpensive ...bettin it's just as good. Gotta get there before 3PM.  
What a find! Especially in San Fran.
author: Al J.

description: What you see is what you get but that said, when you're in the mood for this kind of food you can't beat the price, service or satisfaction. Awesome hashbrowns. Perfect pancakes. I've even tried the burger and it was very decent. But the diner type food mixed with the wonderful service oriented staff makes this one of my favorite go to breakfast spots in SF.
author: Jason P.

description: Dont let the shady appearance fool you- good food and good service. No frills about it which is exactly what i was looking for. And with prices right out of the 80s, i was won over.
author: Jon E.

description:
Great coffee, great traditional American breakfast. 

Service was good too friendly and food came out fast. 

Will def come back!
author: Natty N.

description:
The food here is all so good you'll love what you're having but still be jealous of all the food on other people's plates. The french toast is so fluffy and eggy and perfect. And the hashbrowns are like new york diner perfection. But i don't think any meals have those two items come together. So you have to make some choices or some arrangements with a friend. It's also cheap and I love that you can see everything being made from scratch. 

The only downsides are:

There is no bathroom
You couldn't eat here with a group larger than 4 people
author: Fiona O.

description: Great prices, good food.  Hard to find seats but good cheap diner experience.
author: Martie A.

description: I eat here every weekend. Prices are awesome. It's not out of this world, but the food is pretty good. Biggest complaint is that it's always busy. Can be hard to get a seat if you're with a few friends.
author: Jeran F.

description:
Greasy spoon=perfect breakfast! 

Love, Love, Love this place.  Twice in a few days?!  Uh, so!  With the quintessential counter and stools, with barely any other room to move, this is now at the top of my diner list!  
Walk in and grab a menu...but really do you need a menu?  Eggs, bacon or sausage, white or wheat.  That's pretty much about it.  They also offer sandwiches and some Americanized Chinese food.  But again, the only reason I would ever go into a diner would be for breakfast, so I can't speak to anything else.  The breakfast however is perfect!  And there is almost nowhere in the city where you can eat for 25$!  This was for three of us!  Coffee is okay, but they also make REAL iced tea!  Hot tea, then iced!  Very rare nowadays! 

There could (and probably will be) a line, so wait patiently and it will be worth it!  But don't forget...CASH ONLY!
author: Claire G.

description: This is a great place to go if you are on a budget.  It is a small mostly counter seating  breakfast/lunch place with no frills and no thrills.  Two eggs with hash browns and toast and coffee for around $6.  They only take cash and make sure you tell them exactly how you like things.  Toast comes already buttered and hash brown were a little under done for my taste.  The next day I went there, I specified well done hash browns and no butter on the toast.  Everything went fine after that.
author: Glenn O.

description:
Found this place for breakfast on our first morning in SFO as it opens early and we were still operating on East Coast time.

Good, fast service and great food. Orders cooked one at a time but well worth the wait. This guy can cook on a flat top and it's obviously well-seasoned. Over-easy eggs were truly over easy (kudos). Hash browns perfectly browned but still creamy on the inside. Omelet fluffy and perfect proportion of filling. Corned beef hash caramelized to perfection but still moist (awesome). Bacon cooked a little too hard but that seemed to be the norm in this city.

Would have given this place 5 stars if the hash was house made (hash base from a can) but still a perfect breakfast spot. Would certainly go back again!
author: Brian R.

description: Very nice place! It's small and cozy and seems like you were transported into a small American town. The food is amazing and with friendly prices; the staff is also very nice! I simply loved having tasty breakfast food for lunch.
author: Terezinha S.

description:
This place has the best corn beef hash I have ever had. The other dishes are good but don't match the amazingness of the hash.  Everything is cooked to order and you can see the cook cook everything. Location being right at the edge of the tenderloin and service being a little inattentive make this place not a 5. 

Foods cheap for San Francisco, and you get a ton of it.
author: Brandon A.

description: Hidden little spot, run by a nice old man named Jim."GC" is a great spot to grab morning grub food like French toast and hashbrowns. I had the Spanish omelette and yes, it was fluffy and deeeelicious! I got scared when a lady poked her head out from the floor in the back corner, but I later found out that its where the bathroom is. This is a cheap, yummy little sf gem that seems to have been running for years. Must check out!!
author: Sherry T.

description: This place isn't the fanciest and you should not come here if you expect an IHOP or Denny's type of environment. But expect good food! You should try the Corned Beef Hash.
author: Gian U.

description:
I love this place. It's simple, cheap, tasty and quick.

You basically sit at a bar that's right in front of the kitchen. There are a couple of tables too but's mostly bar seating. The menu is simple. Your food isn't cooked until you order it and then it's cooked right in front of you. The food is tasty and best of all cheap! Service has always been quick, after all you are sitting at a bar right in front of the lady taking everyone's orders. So you're able to get in and out of here pretty quick. It's very old fashioned. It's probably how dinners were back in the '50s but there's nothing wrong with that c:

A burger and fries (both just cooked for you) for only $6.25? A waffle, scrabbled eggs and sausage links for about the same price (or less)? Yeah, I love this little place.

My only complaint is that they don't accept credit/debit cards. Otherwise this would be a five star joint.
author: Vivian A.

description:
My neighborhood go-to when it comes to the classic breakfast/brunch.  Menu is fresh & straightforward; nothing gourmet here, just the classics.  You can get the works for under $10.  Great scrambles & hash browns.  

If you're living a life of fresh-squeezed O.J. and designer coffees of the Blue Bottle-type variety, I'd avoid ordering G.C.'s offerings in those departments.  Grab a coffee at Farm:Table on Post and bring it in.  

I've never waited more than 10 minutes, and that was only when I came with 4 people.  That being said, I usually roll solo or with one friend... that's the best way to do it here since almost all seating is at the bar.
author: M. P.

description:
Dive-y dive-y dive-y breakfast joint, but the food is SO good. The best seats in the house are at the counter, where you can watch your waitress brew your coffee and the cook make your breakfast. It's cheap, it's greasy, the coffee is strong, and the folks who run it need coffee just as much as you do. 

Definitely a great breakfast spot. Oh, and it's wicked cheap.
author: Allison S.

description:
I had breakfast at this friendly, small, family-owned joint on Sunday morning (well, if it had been Sunday afternoon, that would make it "lunch").

I had the Spanish Omelet ~ with mushrooms, onions, & tomato sauce; served with hashbrowns and (whole wheat) toast.

It was all good. I didn't have any breakfast epiphanies, but I wasn't expecting any, either. It was a good meal ~ in a cool little spot ~ and much better than I can ever make on my own. Isn't that why we venture out to these places after all?

If you would care to read a more detailed take on my breakfastary review (and other idiocy), click on my profile here and check out my stupid li'l 'blog thingy.
author: Brian M.

description:
As someone who lived in the South for a few years and grew to love the grimy appeal of Waffle House, I loved this place like I'd love a firstborn child.

The breakfast was the perfect level of cheap and diner-esque [over-easy eggs, toast and hashbrowns. perfect hangover breakfast!] and I loved the counter and communal appeal. Now if only I lived in this neighborhood.
author: Stephani C.

description:
such a great, low key spot in the neighborhood...
I'm probably at this place, at least once a month and I always order the same thing corned beef hash/over easy/ w/ white bread/ coffee & oj 

Nothing much else to say, simple review for a simple spot. 
- inexpensive - fast service - nothing fancy/yummy food - 

I would however warn, this spot can get busy on a weekend morning.
author: Teena Marie T.

description:
There are lots of places you can go for breakfast. There are restaurants. There are diners. There are cafés. There are carts. And then there are greasy spoons. Golden Coffee is the apogee of the greasy spoon. It's got a counter and two cramped tables. It's got all the fare you'd expect. It's cheap. There's always a line on the weekends, but it always moves pretty quickly.

The food is pretty good. Damned good by greasy spoon standards, I guess. And the portions are giant. Perfect for eating your way out of a hangover.

There's even coffee, although it wasn't "golden" by any means.
author: James B.

description:
Boy am I glad we didn't go to Denny's! This spot is your best bet for a straight-forward breakfast:

* Perfectly cooked hash browns and corned beef hash--golden and crispy on the outside, tender on the inside.
* Egg, hamburger and toast were cooked to our exact specifications.
* Service is prompt with a kind charm.
* Great prices. We paid only $16 for 2 breakfasts, coffee plus tax and a generous tip.
* Breakfast is served all day, but they do offer lunch and dinner options as well. 

Support our mom-and-pops! Golden Coffee Shop makes it a no-brainer decision. And, it offers wrap-around counter seating to really make you feel like part of the neighborhood. 

P.S. Bring Cash
author: Savannah L.

description: This place is awesome! Fantastic hole-in-the-wall diner with great prices and delicious food.  I had the Denver Omelet with hash browns, and an order of french toast.  Will definitely be back.
author: Bryce T.

description: Fast fresh cheap. What else do you want? Waffles. Pancakes. Eggs. Bacon. Sausage. All menu items are around $6-8
author: Andrew G.

description: Cheap and yummy breakfast around union square area! When we were there, the shop was full of people, but the service was still very fast. We will definitely go back for breakfast when we visit San Francisco next time.
author: H. W.

description: Although it's a bit grungy, the food is fantastic for the price. Got a corned beef hash plate and was absolutely stuffed after. Definitely recommend.
author: Savi E.

description: This is my favorite breakfast spot in the city. No frills. Just old school simple cheap and good breakfast done well. The old Asian guy is a one man show on the grill and he is what you call a short order cook!  My favorite thing is I can always have rice with my breakfast!  Only 16 counter top seating and 2 tables so it fills up fast everyday!
author: King L.

description:
I suppose that I'm biased, living as I did, three doors down from Golden Coffee for 5 years.  But that doesn't take away from the fact that Golden Coffee serves up pretty good, pretty standard American breakfasts at prices that you haven't seen in a decade or two.

Yes, there's so much grease that you expect the oven hoods to ignite at any moment.  Yes, they only have 14 stools and two cramped tables, but their short-order cook serves up plates of eggs, hash, and pancakes with the speed of a Ferrari and the calm of a Zen Master, and that was good enough for me for many years.
author: Kvatch K.

description:
THIS is what a diner used to be and what a diner should be.

2 eggs, toast, hash browns - $4!
Shrimp omelette - $6+

Mom/Dad/Son/Aunt working there and pleasant.
When we finished, were asked "do you want another piece of toast...?"
All counter seats - love it.

Dad knows how to cook!

Don't tell too many people about it, but do find yourself there and enjoy!
author: Mark M.

description: Love!! I stumbled upon golden coffee almost a year ago (stumbling is quite often the best finds!) and fell in instant love! Bruce and Nancy work like salt and pepper together; great apart but even greater together! A simple, yet tasty breakfast they can do no wrong here. From corned beef hash, which has the perfect crunch, and not too greasy, to my eggs done perfectly over medium (you can tell by the little pop of your fork) to the bacon so wonderfully crunchy. This is breakfast heaven- not for the frills, not for the over sauced, and over priced breakfast you are used to getting here in SF, but for the wonderfully simple and filling breakfast that is consistent every time. Not to mention, I love that Nancy remembers my love for grape jelly and brings it to me every time. Great breakfast!!!
author: Juliana O.

description: Value is my middle name and this place Rocked the Value Chart. Breakfast with coffe tax & Tip $10. I had pancakes and bacon. Pancakes were great bacon only soso. This place isa time capsule from days ago. 3-4 chinese people knocking it out old school all right in front of you. The space is a counter with open kitchen and two small table. Okay coffee. Eggs and hashbrowns looked good. Very slow service ++. hang out, relax have some coffee, read the paper, then eat.
author: Drew B.

description:
Yes. Yes. YES.

Soak up all of last nights poisons here. Fight fire with fire with their down and dirty chinese food or carb load on the eggs and hamburger patty with rice instead of hash browns (smash together into homogenous pile of food and consume).

Indiscernable series of honks/english from the main man is what sells it home. Don't even try hella early on a saturday. You and every other hung over asshole will be trying to swoop one of their 2 tables.
author: Jason M.

description: Denny's can go suck a bag of dicks!!! I 'm dubbing this the best kept secret in SF. Breakfast just like mom used to make. Waffles really good and they're bacon is what I would call perfect.
author: Matt H.

description:
No frills, but that's part of the charm.  This is down-to-business breakfast the old-school way.  

The pancakes are really good.  Thick and fluffy without tasting like baking-powder..  

Hope you like being chatty, because the person next to you is quite close.  But again, that's part of the charm.  Take a stool at the counter and meet the folks in the neighborhood.
author: Christopher M.

description: Why five stars? Cheap food, but it's good and you get what you paid for. The semi-unfriendly waitress and cramped quarters somehow make the eating experience more charming and authentic. I'd go again if I were hungover or in a hurry.
author: Kate P.

description:
This place is so good on a lazy weekend morning. My bf had been frequenting this place on his way to work and decided I needed to try it. We walked in around 1030 on Saturday morning and were lucky that the hangover crowd hadn't wandered over yet. There were maybe 5 people at the counter, and so we took our seats to the far right.

We were promptly handed menus by a quiet and sweet older Asian man - who eventually took our orders. We got:

2 OJs
Joe's special
Corned beef hash with eggs over medium

I had a great view of their makeshift kitchen. And when our orders went through, I was able to watch from beginning to end how they were preparing our food. The cook was speedy and very procedural as he went through making our breakfasts. Nothing looked sketchy or left out that shouldn't have been, and everything was cooked just the way we ordered.

Before it got crazy with bigger parties of twenty-somethings getting their morning fix after a night out, it was actually quite serene. There were three people working -- the man who took our order, a woman who helped with toast, waffles, etc., and the cook -- and they rarely said a word to one another. It was a great start to the morning. They didn't even rush us one bit even when the crowd was building up.

And not to mention -- our entire meal only cost $20 including tip!

We will be back again -- it might even become our go-to breakfast spot.

(And the 4 star rating rather than 5 stars is because it is cash only, the seats can fill up fast, and I'd say a little bit of variety would have been nice to see on the menu.)
author: Alison C.

description:
I came here for a quick good quality breakfast and I was not disapointed.  The place is run by two old Asian guys and one Asian woman.  It has one U-shaped counter and a couple of tables.  The place could handle no more than 20 people.  It has a very mom and pop feel about it which I very much appreciate.  It beats going to Denny's for sure.

I ordered eggs over easy (runny yolks) with hash browns.  And I got exactly that.  The coffee was generic American coffee but good enough for the occasion.
author: Marc W.

description:
Golden Coffee Shop is what it is... except that in doing so it's actually so much more. Unpretentious, good old fashioned morning grub. Don't come if you're looking for organic oatmeal or a fruit plate -- for the days you wake up and need a solid base without selling half your belongings to pay for it, Golden Coffee Shop will serve up fast, tasty, traditional breakfast: waffles, pancakes, french toast, great looking omelets, decent coffee, and the kind of atmosphere you can only achieve with a small, countertop-surrounding-the-kitchen, kinda space. 

Will be going back often!
author: Amanda W.

description: The food is cheap and tasty, french toast, bacon, and typical breakfast food along with salad, soup and rice. Very crowded and only cash.
author: N A.

description: I have been to this hole in the wall, blink and you'll miss it little restaurant three times. Each experience was great. They have cheap, good, healthy breakfast and they cook it right in front of you. For $7 you get eggs, toast, bacon, tomato, and endless coffee. The hospitality and friendliness of the staff/owners also make me keep going back. There is a wrap-around bar around the cooks, and there are 4 tables to sit at as well. Service is quick and efficient.
author: Keagan G.

description: Such a cool mom and pop shop. For breakfast, the prices can't be beat. The pancakes weren't amazing but it's your standard eggs, bacon, hash browns, etc. Just as good or better than Dennys.
author: Avril N.

description: My husband and I stopped here on our way to work for a quick breakfast. I got pancakes with over easy eggs and bacon. He got a berry waffle with the same eggs and bacon. Everything was cooked well and delicious - not to mention Cheap! Great breakfast for such a great price. We'll be back for sure. Just remember - cash only!
author: Emily S.

description: Great restaurant two thumps up. They deserve it for 5 stars. The chef is awesome guy. I totally like how he cook my food. Thanks always be here
author: Athea C.

description: A solid old-school diner. It's got a great layout with a U-shaped counter and big windows, keeping the vibe a little fresher than some other greasy spoons. Crowd is nicely diverse, attracting some Tenderloin characters, a few tourists, and maybe a couple hipsters. Prices are right on- cheap enough that you feel like you're getting a good deal, but not so bargain basement that you start wondering about the quality of the ingredients.
author: Thomas R.

description: I have been so used to being surrounded by these iPad cash resister and hipster waiters. but my husband and I enjoyed this spot because this place is still using paper and wooden ruller and pencil to get orders. one simple open kitchen and U shaped bar front is fun because you can see other customers too. this place's food isn't fancy but it's something you can expect from home.
author: Sj Y.

description: This place is my favorite breakfast place in the city, hands down. Simple food, done right, done quickly, to perfection. May not look like much on the outside, but it's worth it. On the occasional early Saturday that I have to work, I love having my breakfast here amongst all the old men who are early risers. Note: on peak hours, this place may be tough to get into.
author: Jesse G.

description: One of those old school diners that just gets to the point. Ya sit down, shut up and order a meal that seems too good to be true. An omelette with toast and hash browns for 5.50. And a happy Sunday to you too.
author: Lucy F.

description:
So I'm in San Franciso with my wife and 7 year old daughter for a few days. Mom is stuck in meetings all day while me and my little scamp explore the city.  We had the good fortune to stay at the Hyatt at the Embarcadero,, which is the first stop on the California St cable car line. 
   We're looking for breakfast to start our whirlwind days, the type I used to eat back in Brooklyn.  Good old-fashioned breakfast food, eggs, toast, hash browns, waffles, french toast, pancakes, bacon. Not looking for cinnamon-infused breakfast dumplings with a bacon chocolate foam and an eggs benedict  souffle and arugula garnish. Not that theres anything wrong with that. But we wanted to eat.
    The French toast was superb. The pancakes light and fluffy with a HUGE dollop of whipped cream my daughter went wild over..Hearty omlettes, substanial portions, and great prices. We left stuffed for $12 bucks as we went sightseeing and didnt want to eat again until 3..My daughter, a notorious picky eater, devoured her blueberry ancakes...
That says it all. 
     Yes the place is small, but its a nice atmosphere, unpretentious, sometimes quiet, always busy, but if your visiting, you feel like a native, enjoying life like a San Franciscan. Never encountered any freaks that I had to explain to my little angel why this person has a pentagram on their forehead or six rings in their nose.  Enjoy the walk from California down to Sutter and soak up the the neighborhood a bit. A nice local winner!!!
author: Ernest F.

description:
Yum!

I like their waffle w/ strawberries & whip cream.

And

Omelet w/ avocado, cheese, salsa & hash browns.

Both under $6.

Coffee pretty alright, too.

Great breakfast place.
author: Astro S.

description: This is my favorite breakfast place in the city.  At a glance it doesn't look like much, which is great for keeping tourist and tech kids out.  There chef is incredible to watch.  And have never had a bad item on the menu.  Also the price makes it easy to leave a big tip! ( after watching the chef u will see why it's well deserved )
author: Kyle F.

description: This place is cute. It's small, old and run by these Asian folks. Nothing fancy here. But I love that I can get rice (you hafta ask) with my bacon/sausage and eggs for breakfast. They get packed on weekend mornings so prepare to wait. But they get them outta there pretty fast. It's not the type where people will hang out and lounge after they eat their food. You order, eat, pay and go. Cash only.
author: elaine s.

description:
The short answer: Grimy  and small; Great prices, delicious hashbrowns.

I'm no snob, I don't have super-high standards, but this restaurant was absolutely grimy, greasy, and sooty. The window sills and baseboards have a solid black layer of filth at least 1/8 inch thick. 

We were visiting from out of town and just going off the yelp reviews, so we had little idea what to expect. I mean, I figured it would be humble, but it was beyond that. We were a group of 5 and I was the one who suggested it, so it was a little uncomfortable for me when we showed up. 
Honestly, if only we had known how grubby and small it would be ahead of time, it wouldn't have bothered us as much.

Be advised there are only two tables, that each seat 4ish people, and the rest is bar seating, so it isn't great for big groups. Also, there were no bathrooms as far as we could tell, and the Health Dept food grade card was mysteriously missing.

On the positive side: The prices really are good; simple breakfasts for the 5 of us only cost about $31 before tip. The hashbrowns were absolutely fantastic - I'm still thinking about them - perfectly golden and crispy. The service was fairly prompt and decent.

Worth a try if you are prepared for it. No-frills is the understatement of the century.
author: Lisa S.

description:
Came here today for the first time.  Outstanding, no-frills, plentiful, delicious breakfast, with awesome coffee.  I had the joe's special omelette and my wife had the veggie omelette, both with egg whites and hash browns.  

But, best of all -- besides the coffee -- three hot sauces to choose from, right on the counter. Including my favorite, the chili garlic sauce that usually comes in the plastic container with the green top.  

We'll definitely be back.
author: Paul K.

description: I love this mom & pop shop, nothing fancy or fussy. The food is good for the price. I usually get the french toast or waffle, depending on my mood. My boyfriend always gets the corned beef hash. The seating is stools wrapped around the counter so you get cozy with fellow dinners. I just like this place because it feels old school. My only complaint is that they have an exhaust fan moving outside air, and when it is turned on, it has a low hum that makes me feel dizzy. That's probably just my issue, but it can be disorienting.
author: Halley S.

description:
Was here Jan 2011.  Ate here a total of 2 or 3 times on this trip.  Couldnt really beat the location and food.  This place was so close to our hotel and the food was comparable to most breakfast places.

Had standard stuff like bacon n eggs, pancakes.  No complaints on any visit.  Price was great.  Friendly staff.

The place wasnt much to look at but dont let that deter you.
author: Laine D.

description:
I'm going to be completely honest and tell you that I don't want to write a 5 star review for this place for fear that it will get too popular and when I eat here every week there won't be any seats.


I. Love. This. Place.



I have yet to try their lunch just because the breakfast is so damn good. 

There are the same 3 people working every single day and they are so sweet and attentive. 

Also, the price is unbeatable. My boyfriend and I get two orders of french toast, two orders of hash browns and two coffees and it's only $15? Awesome.

Be warned though, it's cash only!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
The Golden Coffee Shop was the first restaurant that came-up in my Yelp search for a cheap, tasty breakfast that was within walking distance of the Hotel Triton.  It was a beautiful day up in the city and we took a 15-minute walk to make it to the Golden Coffee Shop.  it's a total hole-in-the-wall, with only counter seating available;  all of which was pretty much all taken.  We shoe horned ourselves into two corner seats and took a look at the menu.  

The menu was totally bare bones with just the basics and nothing too fancy which is exactly we wanted.  I ordered a spinach and mushroom omelet with hash browns and a cup of coffee.  They have an open kitchen so I could watch the cook make my breakfast.   When my order arrived, the hash browns were crispy (totally an A+ for me) and the omelet was simple, and hit the spot. 

Great breakfast place, and for the price a total steal.  For the 2 of us, it was under $20.  Yes.  $20 for 2 people in the city.  Great find in the city and if you want something no-frills this is it!
author: Eugene F.

description:
+1 fast service (not as much if you're sitting at either of the 2 tables, they kind of forget you exist) 
+1 food is good, home style cooking 
+1 cheap ($5-$8 a plate) 

Mom and pop place. Great for a quick bite. Only place I know (besides home) where you can get rice with your eggs!
author: A B.

description: Joes Special: Quite possibly the best omelette I've ever tasted. This little  "greasy spoon" restaurant was the best place to come upon during my stay in SF. Kind of a hidden gem, the Golden Coffee Shop is one chef cooking and two waitresses collecting orders and cleaning up. No tricks behind the curtain, instead you see how he makes what you ordered. Sure, there may be a little wait since seating is like a bar, but it is completely worth it! Warning: Cash only!
author: Andrew P.

description: Golden Coffee is worthy of a quick bite to eat, and despite my low rating I do eat here often. The food is average, and cheap. The restaurant is incredibly dated, and the service leaves a little to be desired.
author: Greg B.

description: It was good food.  Just what we wanted.  Plain good breakfast, right in the middle of San Francisco. Bacon, lots of it and eggs...all ways plus toast.  Great prices...hard to believe they can do that!! Keep it up, loved it
author: Don S.

description: Totally love the downtown feel.  A small cafe you would walk by without noticing it until a friend invites you, it is located on the corner and surrounded by windows so you can get the busy city walkers and still enjoy your breakfast & coffee inside in an intimate setting.  The seats are limited, but clean and you can see everything the staff does.  Breakfast is so cheap, you can get two eggs, hash browns, toast, and a side meat under $7.00!  Cash Only though!
author: Neville B.

description: Great prices - good food - friendly faces. Very at-home diner experience. I'm certain I would be a regular if I lived in the neighborhood.
author: David G.

description:
LOVE this place!!!
You cant go wrong with a bagel, hashbrowns and 3 slices of bacon with yummy oj for under 8 bucks!

This is what breakfast needs to be. Simple. None of this organic-low cal-low carb food or some frappe latte macchiato bullshit. 

Cheap. Delicious. Honest people. What's not to love?

I have yet to eat anything besides breakfast here. And I probably won't. And I'm ok with that. Golden Coffee will always have my business!
author: Amanda S.

description:
All counter seats - and two tables. Being from New Jersey - the birthplace of diners, this is exactly what a diner should be! Breakfast for less than $6 with quick service. Corned Beef Hash, Two Scrambled Eggs, Hashbrowns and Toast for $5.50! 

Food was made quick to order - tasted excellent; and they even had a free 
newspaper to read. Place appeared to be full of mostly locals.

Cash Only!
author: Brian D.

description:
This place is kind of funny.  Different, too.

The restaurant is basically a U-shaped counter, with customers on the outside and one man on the inside taking orders.  He takes the order and give it to the one single cook, whose in the same room as you in plain sight, at the top of the U, cooking food..  The only other employee(?) I could see was a woman who was constantly going downstairs to get supplies.

This unique business model works.  The waiter-guy is always in the center of the U, so it's easy to get his attention.  He, the cook, and the lady seemed to be telepathically linked because things moved along really smoothly without much interaction between them.

The reason they get 4 stars is because you have to sit really close to other diners, and the food was just OK, nothing spectacular or even above-average.  It's the staff, the sheer uniqueness, prices, location, and the name of the place that gets Golden Coffee Shop its high marks.
author: Paul G.

description: A classic greasy spoon. The kitchen is open for viewing but I suggest to not watch. Bring cash or you will be washing dishes to pay for breakfast. An awesome value in the heart of the city. 2 eggs, 2 toast, 4 sausage and hash browns for $5.25 is just silly.
author: Katie J.

description:
Literally stumbled into this place totally by accident. Not much to look at, but don't let that put you off. Food is cheap and cheerful and lots of it. Smiley staff, fast service and a belly full of chow. Its a bit short on seating, so there is a bit of a Q sometimes,  but its a good indicator.

Put yer ass on a stool here for a bite - you won't regret it...
author: Broken B.

description:
This place is dirty, and it ain't so cheap.
My friend saw a rat run across the floor. 
I wouldn't let me mother eat here, nor would she choose to.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I really don't know the last time I ate a piece of white bread. When did I stop eating it? Why did I give it up? It certainly wasn't a conscious decision I made one day. Somehow my life simply stopped including plain white bread and I never noticed...until I hit up Golden Coffee Shop for a quick pick-me-up breakfast.

There ain't nothing fancy here. Just grab a seat at the counter and order up your bacon, egg and hash brown breakfast. Pull out some reading material and enjoy the simplicity you've been missing from your life.

Whole grains, organic eggs, and rosemary potatoes can wait for another day.
author: Michelle B.

description: Keep up the good work guys! The food is tasty, the joint is cozy  and you will not find a cheaper breakfast in the city. Golden coffee is the gem of the tendernob
author: Emily B.

description: Breakfast was good, fast n cheap. First time at this place and will return for more when I'm in the area, good family owned spot in The City.
author: Jaime P.

description: This place is cheap, yummy, and fast. I love coming here for a simple breakfast on the weekends. Their hash browns are favorite, and I don't know what they put in their coffee but... oh so delicious.
author: Lucinda W.

description: Great breakfast place, fast service,cheap and good food. The corn beef hash and eggs are sooo good here. awesome hole in the wall place if your looking for quick breakfast.
author: Bobina B.

description: As good as it'll get for straight up breakfast. The french toast is amazing. I get hot flashes just thinking about it.
author: Kenny K.

description: This place does one thing and it does it well. Offers cheap breakfast and lunch at an affordable price and offers it quickly.  This is truly a no frills place where the only decorations you will find are two calendars on the wall.  But the pancakes were filling and the coffee was just what I needed to face another day of sightseeing.  This place is tiny with only two 4 top tables and a few counter side seats.  It gets busy but people are in and out pretty quickly.
author: Jessica F.

description:
This review was supposed to be about my adventure to Sears Fine Food but due to an extra long wait and the place filled with Union Square Holiday shoppers we had to think quickly on our feet and adjust our plans. 

After a late late late late late late late night of schmoozing at our annual Holiday party we woke up early and just were not in the mood to to eat breakfast in a stuffy hotel setting. Plus I had been wanting forever to check out the Swedish pancakes at Sears Fine Food. We made our way down the hill only to find the place beyond packed. I (we) were hungry for a quality greasey spoon breakfast and we were not going to be denied. 

My friend mentioned a place up the hill on Sutter which I mistakenly thought it was a different place near my Dentist office. That place never appealed and I almost nixed it but my friend was insistent that it was "my kind of place" that this place is the quintessential with the greasiest breakfast food in the entire city and about as "low profile" a place could possibly be. 

I must admit I was a bit pouty as we walked up the hill and thinking we were heading to Loris Diner or a Denny's. It was Sunday December 13th and this date I will now never forget as I found the mother of all grease spoon diners. The minute you spot it you would swear that you have discovered what inspired Edward Hopper to paint. This place is about as no frills as you can get. The diner has one large u-shaped counter with simple swivel stools and just one lonely table by the window. No fancy signage or TGIF type menus. Just your basic city diner with the simplest of menus. At this point I had fallen in love and it didn't even matter what the food tasted like. This place is beyond perfect for me. 

Bu yes, I should review the food. On this day I went with the corned beef hash and eggs. The eggs were over medium and perfectly cooked. The corned beef has was heavenly and not too fancy like those earthy organic places you would find in Marin. Theirs was simple with juicy bits of potatoes in each bite. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. 

The only drawback is their hot chocolate as it was on the sweet side. I'm not sure why diners can never serve a decent cup of hot cocoa. I ended up just asking for a cup of coffee where I dumped a gallon of cream and 90 ounces of sugar in it. I know I know, I was just blasting the sweet hot cocoa and kind of sort of contradicting myself right now. 

Soma Inn Cafe is still my favorite breakfast spot in the City, but if you are looking for ambiance you can do no better than stumbling in here at 11:00 in the morning.
author: V B.

description:
cheap food.

nothing special.  but you cant ask for much more at this price.
author: Addison P.

description: Cheap, but pretty greasy and the ambiance just isn't! Will probably look for other breakfast places.
author: Michelle L.

description: Great breakfast food, amazing prices, old school feel. Place looks a little dingy but dont let that scare you away.
author: Natasha P.

description: One of the few places in SF where you can get rice with your eggs and sausage. If you want an Asian style breakfast (eggs over easy running all over your rice), this is the place to go. Rice is a side dish that can be substituted for toast, but you have to ask for it.
author: michelle e.

description: A proper greasy spoon with out Big Trouble in Little Intestine. The old fellow that runs the griddle seems to have been doing his thang forever, and for damn sure has it down. Scoring some expertly executed French toast and sausage is like cutting into a sticky sweet simile on a well-worn plate of analogies. It can get crowded on the weekends but on weekdays, it's a nice spot to grab a bite right in the student hub on Sutter. And if you're anything like this girl I heard on the corner, and you're saying, "It's Friday. I think I wanna get a little crazy," I suggest you first dial Field Marshall Tecate and Admiral Hornitos for some nasty type night moves, then make a date with this little number come Saturday morn, limp back home, have a good deuce, then watch that marathon of Parking Wars.
author: Roy M.

description:
The New York Strip/Eggs is awesome. Been twice with my boyfriend - both times they nailed cooking a truly med rare steak &eggs over easy perfect(no runny white) - Great hashbrowns; We can share it &be totally stuffed. $9.95 - with coffee (free refills) + tip/tax out the door 15$.
Great neighborhood place! - just don't look at the peach & teal paint ; ) but guess part of charm if lookin for that mom&pop diner atmosphere...HOWEVER, WISH ADD EGGS BENEDICT TO MENU PLEASE, PLEASE! Would be there daily! And get 5 stars!
My guy been tryin to get me to go for a year & I refused - but now I'm hooked! It's kinda good for those 7am mornings during the week when ya need a pick-me-up before work. Not so crowded like weekends. Pretty relaxed/ cool way to start day!
author: Kelsie F.

description: It might be the smallest place we've been for breakfast but its worth the stop. Watching the chef work his magic on each ticket right in front of you. Bring cash. This guy can crack an egg like no other.
author: Scott S.

description:
I must eat breakfasts - it's the most important meal of my day, and the Golden Coffee Shop is one of my favorite places in Union sq. district! I've tried multiple breakfast places within the area, and this one stays on top of them. I eat there at least once a week and been happy every time.

The food is extra DELICIOUS at this place! I've tried omelets all around the city, and couldn't believe that there could be so much difference, but this place makes it taste better than others, and a very very reasonable prices! If you like meat, try their Joe's Special omelet, it's awesome!
author: Serge U.

description:
Since i lived in this area, this was my first choice of Breakfast place to eat. Why i love this place? it's a simple as other people would say the same as me. Cuz this place is good, great food, good decent coffee under $10 (per person) 

I like to order my bacon omelet with extra cheese and a cup of coffee from the breakfast menu but if i come here on afternoon i would like to get my chicken chow-mein, Yum yum!
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
Five dollars for breakfast? Are you sure? I bet it's a terrible breakfast, right?

Absolutely not! Eggs, bacon, hash browns, and toast. All made to perfection, short-order-cook style. This place is excellent -- superior, in fact -- for breakfast. As the other reviews have noted, there's no fancy-pants gourmet stuff here: just your good old American basics.

The only problem? On the weekends, there might be a wait.
author: Mark W.

description: The food was great, coffee hot. Maybe the service is better if you sit at the counter, we chose a window seat. A lot of locals hangout here, which is always a good sign.
author: Noe T.

description:
Golden Coffee shop is a great inexpensive not so greasy "greasy spoon" type of breakfast joint.  There are 3 adorable older people that run the place.  The two old guys that cook and serve the food move at a pace that makes you think your eggs are more likely to hatch than to be cooked.  Just when you are starting to think you should have gone somewhere that has upgraded their decor since opening 40 years ago, then like an act of magic, a perfectly cooked dish is set in front of you (and a coffee warm-up).
Bottom line, this place is the exactly what the standard breakfast place should be.  No-frills, just people that know how to cook, keep a clean place and truly appreciate your business.
author: Troy S.

description:
I LOVE GOLDEN COFFEE! My boyfriend and I discovered it when we moved onto Post St. last summer and were obsessed after our first breakfast of eggs, hash browns, toast and coffee that amounted to a whopping $5.50!!!!!

I have NEVER eaten breakfast that cheap in this city. The truth is there are no frills, you sit at a bar and are surrounded by really ugly pink walls, but who CARES! The food is good, the people who own and operate it are sweet as can be and the ridiculously low price should be enough to encourage your visit, if nothing else.

Sometimes we go 2 or 3 mornings in a row because nothing cures a hangover like a good, cheap, hot breakfast. 

You should try to sit at the bar though, as sitting at the table you get slightly slower service. It is also cash-only, so keep that in mind.

Golden Coffee is my favorite place. Sometimes when I'm out at night, I get excited about the prospect of going the next morning.

Go to Golden Coffee, you won't regret it.
author: Ashley B.

description:
Passed by Dottie's as my first choice where the line, per so many reviews, was at least 15 deep on a chilly Thursday morning at 9. Six minutes later I'm plunked down at The Golden with a brimming hot cup of eminently palatable joe and not giving a thought to those erstwhile shivering souls. Most of the seats surround the bar, though there are at least two tables for parties of four. Place was half full for most of my 45 minutes there. One of the tables became occupied for about thirty minutes. Aside from a dad-son combo and the table of four, the patrons sat singly at the bar. 

The ham and cheese omelet with wheat toast and hash browns were as good as eggs and potatoes can be though the side of four bacon strips proved to be somewhat rubbery. Service: low-key friendly, punctual, non-intrusive. 

If you're looking for a breakfast "experience" with the spouse, friends or those who like to scrutinize breakfast menus for exotically slathered pancakes, consider standing in line elsewhere. If you want a basic, great-tasting breakfast with decent coffee, take your newspaper along and forge your own "experience" with no glitz and no lines.
author: David W.

description: Very friendly staff and clean. Food is cheap and reasonable size
author: Shakei D.

description:
Repeat after me, "BO-DE-GA'!!!! Thats exactly what I felt when I stepped into Golden Coffee Shop. I imagine people playing cards downstairs, maybe a small bar and who can forget, Cock Fighting. Who can forget the first time they cooked breakfast. There were plenty of dishes to clean, the eggs where too runny. The pancakes were deformed and not perfectly circled and the hot water tasted like coffee? I remember those days....and you can too!!!! Take a seat inside the restaurant and GCS will take you back to those more innocent days and now its only $8.99!!!!!Wow!!!!

   Call me NEW SCHOOL but having breakfast should be enjoyed. Every bite should be an explosion of flavors in your mouth or else why waste you hard earn money, or better yet, your time (maybe I am just preaching cause I took my wife to see EAT PRAY LOVE...great movie btw). I was expecting good food and all I got was food. Next time if you are hungry and dont care about the taste, go to GCS or be like me, grab a Cliff bar. Ellas, here we come!!!!!!!!!
author: Edson C.

description: Is a nice place for breakfast, simple not so pretty , but nice service good food and thats all u need to keep moving in the morning
author: Larry L.

description:
Good home cooked food. A locals place, but the bad point here is not much seating mainly old bar style.

CASH ONLY!
author: Sean M.

description: I was walking to dotties place since so many people was raving about it I stumble upon this place. It was awesome and very cheap for breakfast.  I've been coming to SF for years and never had breakfast this economical. If your going to open up your own biz this would be it. A small no frills breakfast and lunch spot. The service was good.. their are only 3 workers in the place.. but it definently was not short on customers... people were waiting for a spot..  But this is the cheapest and tasty breakfast I have ever had in SF
author: Attaicus C.

description:
Awesome pace that will fix you a simple breakfast. Nothing fancy, service is decent, it's more of a neighborhood joint.
Basically, you come in, sit at the counter, order, eat, pay and leave! (20 minutes top)
If you crave for eggs and hash and are looking for $6 breakfast, that's the place to go to. 
I wouldn't recommend going there to catch up with friends.
author: Christian P.

description:
After two failed attempts to have breakfast due to wait, my friend and I headed back to her car trying to figure out where to eat. We stood at the corner trying to decide what to do, and I finally notice that we were standing in front of a shoddy looking diner. There were a lot of people sitting and eating and I was desperate so we decided to go in, even if it looked like of like a dive place. The menu was simple and I already knew I wanted an omlette. A minute after sitting down, I ordered myself a Joe's Special and my friend got the strawberry waffle.

The food came fairly quickly and was actually fairly decent. The atmostphere was probably my favorite thing about this place. The walls, the counter, everything about this place is plain and kind of dull... but it warms my heart seeing the Chinese family that owns it just running it and having their hard work pay off. The crowd is very much local and it feels like a typical American breakfast place.

$6 for my Joe's Special which included toast and hash brown. Add T&T, I paid about $7.50 for the entire meal--half of which I took with me to work and ate for lunch. Can't exactly beat that price considering the amount of food I got. Enjoyed it greatly; I would again if I happened to be in the neighborhood.
author: Annie Y.

description:
As a college student I absolutely LOVE Golden Coffee. I live down the block from this little diner and as a local in the area for three years I find it very charming. I have even made a few friends just going there alone for the coffee and some breakfast. 

I've read some of the more negative reviews and all I have to say is this.
-If you are someone who is afraid of talking or sitting next to strangers DO NOT GO HERE. More often than not you will be sitting next to someone you may find odd, but as an artist I find these people amazing and they always have great stories to tell. 
-This place is not good for big families. The seating is limited and as most of us that go there are regulars we ask you keep your kids from being obnoxious and running around, we will not hesitate to grill and eat them. 
-The coffee is no Blue Bottle mind you, but in my book their coffee tastes great (as opposed to Denny's ass coffee) and will wake you up in minutes! That's what I love.
-The food tastes really great and the portions are just right! It's cash only but breakfast for one will cost you around $5, maybe $8 max depending on what you get. 
-They don't only serve breakfast, they have lunch as well.
-The menu is limited so if you are looking to be wow'd, don't go there. It's a simple diner with simple food. 
-The atmosphere is that of your grandma's 70's style kitchen almost. I personally love it because it has character. I have never seen a rat or a roach. 

Would I travel across town to go there? Not really because I am rather lazy when it comes to trekking across the city for a meal much less breakfast. I still love this place though. :)
author: Brie S.

description: Pretty good place for breakfast even though I ate lunch. I have lived a block away, and have been anxious to try it.  I got a omlette with jack cheese, avocado, and salsa, #19. The place was about 25% filled, and  a soon as I sat down the place started to fill. The interior is a square shape with a horse shoe like bar with stools. The food came pretty quick after I ordered the toast came first, then the omlette. The omlette was cooked, and the avocadoes were fresh. The salsa came from a large container which isn't bad, just informing. The plate also came with hash browns, but I'm not a great fan of them in general. Overall this place is cheap, and pretty good, the bill was 6.30$.
author: Nathan M.

description:
Golden Coffee Shop : TenderNob ::
Denny's : Any-Town, USA (minus the 24-hour part)

Need breakfast but too lazy to make it yourself but still want to stay in your pjs or sweats? Too poor to shell out more than 10 bucks? Too impatient to wait in that ungodly line at Dottie's or Olea because you're hungry NOW? If you don't mind sitting around a bunch of artsy hipsters in thrift store clothes then Golden Cafe is the answer! It's dingy, small, and cheap. The owners are people of few words but are super sweet. Here you'll get a breakfast that you could've made yourself but you paid someone else to do it for you. ~$5 for 3 pieces of french toast and 2 eggs. I'm there.
author: Kristine W.

description: Great lil mom n' pop style place. Prices can't be beat. The bacon was good quality and cooked perfectly. Breakfast served all day. Fried rice, chow mein and other randoms on the menu makes it easy for those who don't want breakfast at noon.
author: Anna N.

description:
No frills here.  This is the type of place you go to after a rough night out when you looking for some greasy foods.  This old school little diner has about 15-20 seats that are around a U-shaped counter top.  There are two small tables that hold 4 people each.  

Small simple menu with a small variety of different breakfast and lunch options.  I had the Joe's omelette with hash browns and toast.  Total cost was 7.45 after tax.  Made for a good, quick, easy, and cheap meal.  Friendly service too.  Was in and out the door in 20 minutes or so.
author: Frankie O.

description:
People who come here looking for gourmet food and then leave disappointed are coming to the wrong place to begin with. This is a roll up your sleeves, blue collar, eat here every day, drop down the cash before the check comes kind of place. 

Eat here because you know and love what you want in the first place. Order the french toast because that is your favorite, not because it has some exotic spin on it. Order an omelet because that's exactly what you need, not because it comes with organic soy chorizo.

Sit down, shut up, and drink your mediocre coffee. Rub shoulders at the bar with neighbors, know that single ten dollar bill in your wallet will cover more than anything you could order, and leave damn glad places like this still exist.
author: Johnathan Y.

description: Seriously bad food. We went here after reading reviews on yelp, and let me tell you.....it was bad! Tiny place, a total staff of 2. And tone was the cook. It wasn't clean and the food was terrible. I'm not sure how anyone can screw up eggs, bacon and toast, but they did. The fried eggs must  have been cooked on a dirty griddle with old recycled oil. really bad!
author: Shannon C.

description:
Love this little breakfast spot.

If I'm up early enough, it's definitely #1 on my list. The price is unbeatable and the service is top notch for being a greasy spoon. Get here early tho, as seating is very limited.
author: Ed D.

description: I popped into Golden Coffee, which was adorably local.  This was the definition of a Mom and Pop.  Snagged a burger and fries for $6.  Basically half of what Pearl's was going to charge me a few blocks over.  Nothing to complain about here.  Good and cheap eats.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
i love golden,  i've been eating here for over 10 years.  not once have i ever gotten sick or grossed out.  this is so rare living downtown.

great vegetable chow mein, some of the best in the city.  hashbrowns are crispy and fresh, odwalla orange juice is served instead of the cheap crap around the way.  oh, those scrumptious fries!

always the same cook (owner), servers, and i love that classical music is generally playing.  OK, it's not the most elegant, but you can't beat the prices and the kind service with delicious food.

at one time i used to LOVE the chicken soup, best in the TL.  no meat for me now, more for you!

cash only.
author: Noel J.

description:
What a crappy way to start Patricia P and I's hungover brunch/lounge day!  I notice this place on my walk to the gym everyday.  I finally crossed the street one day and decided to take a look @ their menu which is super cheap.  So I obviously yelped it right then and there on the trusty iphone and learned that it had a rating of FOUR stars.

So we decided to try it out today.  Patricia P texted me about how she was concerned with the deliciousness level and I convinced her that it was a 4 star joint, so it had to be pretty quality.

I ordered a denver omelet with avocado and she ordered the waffles with a side of sausage and hashbrowns.  They first drop off my toast. Five mins later, Patty gets her janky looking waffle.  Five mins after that, she gets her sausage and hashbrowns.  Finally, five-ish mins after that, I get the rest of my food. Unacceptable.

My eggs were actually pretty good, but nothing else was.  I don't think this place is worth it.
author: Jenny W.

description: If you're looking for a simple breakfast, Golden Coffee Shop is your place.  Service is fast and efficient, food is delicious and cheap.  I got the corn beef hash and it was cooked to perfection, nice and crispy on the outside.  After tips and tax, your breakfast will cost you about $8/person.  The place is pretty small, so there might be a short wait.
author: Veronica N.

description: A very barebones breakfast joint for REALLY cheap. Don't expect any thrills, but for a nice breakfast without any hassle, Golden Coffee hits the spot if you know what you're in for.
author: Darius Y.

description:
Popping in here on weekend mornings is one of my favorite rituals, for sure. 

The food is greasy spoontastic, and the portions are proper so there's not much guilt to go along with it. It's extremely consistent; the hash browns are just great, my eggs are always cooked perfectly, and I honestly haven't had anything so far that hasn't been really, really tasty.

Service can be just a little bit wonky sometimes, which is the only reason this isn't a 5-star review. Most of the time though, it's perfectly fine. I definitely enjoy watching the family who runs the place going about their work; they're hard-nosed yet still decently friendly.

It's kind of too bad that people have reviewed this place badly for not serving up some kind of intricate, innovative brunch. You really ought to be able to tell that's not what you're getting by looking at the menu for two seconds.
author: Tracy C.

description:
I am a sucker for diners and this one reeks of the sort of diner you might find on a long back road drive, in a small rundown town somewhere on your travels in the deep South... the sort of town where an older Asian couple run a diner complete with a back page of chow mein and fried rice dishes. 

The food is cheap - a complete breakfast can be had for under $5. This is probably because they put absolutely no money into decorating this place. There is a horseshoe shaped formica counter and the flourecent lights are an afterthought to the natural light pouring in the front windows. There is an air of greasiness. Its not one that necessarily makes you feel dirty, but rather, foreshadows what to expect out of your meal. On the mauve walls you will find 2 calendars, freebies from some distributor they likely use. Other than that the place is stark. 

I like it that way, as it puts all of the attention on the customers, who bring a flavor all their own, so its sort of like getting an extra side with your cheap eats.
author: Drue C.

description:
The wait staff is average, both in speed and friendliness.  Average comfort in the stools along the u-shaped bar.  Average diner coffee.  Average morning parking in the neighborhood.  Average food quality (and like most other average diners, they have no idea what "eggs over medium" means), with just enough grease to help take the edge off a rough morning.

I think I've only ever seen two people working here -- the polite and reserved waiter and the cook, who appears to have a permanent hunch from working the griddle.  

But it's damned cheap.  One egg, two sausage, a slab of hashbrowns, a few slices of toast, and a cup of coffee isn't going to run you more than $8 after tax & tip.  I think they're passing on the money they saved by putting up absolutely zero decorations onto you, the hungry and broke customer.
